sections.title: Jaw joint problems, clenching, and facial pain
sections.body:
Problems involving the jaw joints (TMJ), clenching or grinding (bruxism), and facial muscle pain are common and often interconnected.

Symptoms can range from mild discomfort to persistent pain, headaches, or difficulty opening and closing the mouth.

At St Mary’s House Dental Care, these issues are approached carefully, with an emphasis on understanding causes rather than jumping to conclusions.
bullets: Jaw joint, clenching, and facial pain can be linked
Symptoms range from mild discomfort to persistent pain
Care focuses on understanding causes first

sections.title: Common symptoms
items: Jaw or facial pain
Clicking or grating sounds from the jaw joints
Headaches, often on waking
Ear or temple discomfort
Tooth wear, fractures, or jaw stiffness

sections.title: Understanding TMJ and bruxism
sections.body:
The temporomandibular joints (TMJ) allow the jaw to move smoothly during speaking, chewing, and swallowing.

Bruxism refers to clenching or grinding of the teeth, often occurring during sleep but sometimes during waking hours.

Muscle activity, bite factors, stress, and habits can all influence how these systems behave. Rarely is there a single cause.
bullets: TMJ joints support smooth jaw movement
Bruxism is clenching or grinding, often during sleep
Muscle activity, bite, stress, and habits play a role
Most cases have more than one contributing factor

sections.title: Assessment and diagnosis
items: Symptoms reviewed alongside jaw, muscle, and tooth function
Checks for jaw movement, muscle tenderness, and bite relationships
Assessment of wear patterns and contributing factors
X-rays or 3D imaging used when needed to clarify findings
Diagnosis is usually clinical with gradual decision-making

sections.title: Management and treatment options
items: Treatment tailored to the individual and often starts conservatively
Monitoring and advice on habits and jaw use
Splint therapy when appropriate
Address contributing dental factors
Approaches may be combined over time
sections.strapline: The aim is to reduce strain, protect teeth, and improve comfort — not to force the jaw into a particular position.

sections.title: What to expect over time
items: Jaw-related symptoms often fluctuate
Improvement can take time
Treatment may be adjusted based on response
Regular review keeps management appropriate
We discuss what can reasonably be expected

sections.eyebrow: When further investigation may be needed
sections.title: When further investigation may be needed

faqs.question: When might further investigation be needed?
faqs.answer: If symptoms worsen, fail to improve, or are associated with swelling, locking, or neurological changes, further investigation may be recommended. We’ll explain the reasons clearly and discuss appropriate referral or imaging where needed.

sections.title: Questions and reassurance
sections.body:
Jaw pain and facial discomfort can be worrying, especially when symptoms persist.

If you’re unsure what’s causing your symptoms or what the next step should be, we encourage you to ask. Understanding the problem is often the first step toward improvement.
bullets: We explain possible causes and next steps
Questions are encouraged if you feel unsure
Understanding the problem is part of improvement
